explanation:
- OS_filesys_internal_record_t: Need the struct definition (types of members) to see whether virtual_mountpt is declared as char[] or const char[] and whether flags is mutable. This determines if the function could/should take a pointer-to-const to the filesys record or to its virtual_mountpt member.
- OS_filesys_table: The table/object that OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET indexes into — its declaration/element type shows whether entries are intended to be mutable or read-only (affects whether filesys can be const-qualified).
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: The macro/function used to obtain filesys; its expansion/signature and return type determine whether the API requires a mutable pointer (precluding returning/using a const-qualified pointer) or if a const-qualified pointer could be used here.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Often used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; its prototype/semantics may impose non-const requirements on the returned record or token usage and thus affect whether filesys or token pointers can be const.
- OS_object_token_t: The token type definition confirms whether the token parameter is already const-correct and whether any operations on it would require removing const qualification.
- OS_common_record_t: Present in the function signature (obj parameter). Its definition helps assess whether the signature should use const for that parameter (even though unused here) and for overall API const-correctness.
- OS_FILESYS_FLAG_IS_MOUNTED_VIRTUAL: The flags macro/type and how flags are stored (in flags member type) are needed to confirm only read access is performed; if checking flags requires modification elsewhere, that could affect whether the filesys pointer may safely be const here.
- OS_strnlen: The prototype (first parameter type) confirms it accepts a const char *; this supports treating virtual_mountpt and the target string as const-qualified when only read.

Together these symbols let an analyst determine whether any of the objects accessed by OS_FileSys_FindVirtMountPoint must be mutable (preventing const qualification) or whether the function could/should declare its pointer parameters/locals as pointing to const-qualified types to comply with the MISRA rule.
